title: What number when multiplied by itself is 11 greater in the preceding number when it is multiplied by itself? - Quora

response.answer_text: We have observed that difference between the squares of adjacent numbers is equal to the sum of those adjacent numbers. It is also equal to (2 × smaller number) + 1. That is, 1^2 - 0^2 = 1 + 0 = 2×0 + 1 2^2 - 1^2 = 2 +1= 2×1 + 1 3^2 - 2^2 = 3 +2 = 2×2 + 1 9^2 - 8^2 = 9 + 8 = 2×8 + 1, etc. In the given problem question, let “x” & “(x + 1) be the two adjacent numbers the difference between whose squares is 11. Then, as per the above observation, (x + 1)^2 - ×^2 = (x + 1) + x = 2x + 1. As per the data in the question, 2x + 1 = 11. That is, 2x = 10. That is, x = 5, and (x + 1) = 6. Thus, the greater number = 6 is the ANS. (Note: 6^2 - 5^2 = 36 - 25 = 11 = 6 + 5 = 2×5 + 1)

Let x be a number whose preceding number is x-1 . x when multiplied itself = ( x)×(x)= (x)^2. Preceding number when multiplied by itself = (x-1)×(x-1)= (x-1)^2. , accordingly :- (x)^2-(x-1)^2=11. or, x^2-x^2+2x-1=11 or, 2x=12 => x = 12\2 = 6. , Answer.
